title: auxiliaryfunctions.GetScorerName() not working
body:
**Description** Following the multi-animal tracking workflow described here: https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/blob/master/docs/functionDetails.md, in section (I) when trying to create a video with all detections, the function `auxiliaryfunctions.GetScorerName(config_path, shuffle, trainFraction)` is causing an error. **Desktop** - OS: Ubuntu 18.04 (Google Colab) - DeepLabCut Version: 2.2b8 - DeepLabCut mode: multi-animal tracking - Browser: Mozilla Firefox 82.0.3 **To Reproduce** 1. Follow all steps up to here: https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/blob/master/docs/functionDetails.md#i-novel-video-analysis 2. After running `deeplabcut.analyze_videos()` successfully, I want to obtain the `scorername` to include in: ```python deeplabcut.create_video_with_all_detections(config_path, video_path, DLCscorername=scorername) ``` 3. See error:
TRACEBACK

```python scorername, DLCscorerlegacy = deeplabcut.auxiliaryfunctions.GetScorerName(config_path, shuffle=1, trainFraction=0.95) --------------------------------------------------------------------------- TypeError Traceback (most recent call last) in () ----> 1 scorername, DLCscorerlegacy = deeplabcut.auxiliaryfunctions.GetScorerName(config_path, shuffle=1, trainFraction=0.95) /usr/local/lib/python3.6/dist-packages/deeplabcut/utils/auxiliaryfunctions.py in GetScorerName(cfg, shuffle, trainFraction, trainingsiterations, modelprefix) 529 """ 530 --> 531 Task = cfg["Task"] 532 date = cfg["date"] 533 TypeError: string indices must be integers ```

**Expected behavior** A tuple `(scorername, DLCscorerlegacy)` to be returned. **Screenshots** **Additional context** The documentation provides the line: ```python scorername, DLCscorerlegacy = auxiliaryfunctions.GetScorerName(config_path, shuffle, trainFraction) ``` I needed to add `deeplabcut.` in front of the function. It may also be good to get some guidance on what the `trainFraction` is (i.e. where to find it in the `config.yaml`). I used `0.95` because that's what is underneath `TrainingFraction:` in that file. Cheers, Ian
